title: 115_s3459
content: The curr_chunk is about disability rights. Congress does not directly appropriate funds for the ADA Mediation Program of the Disability Rights Section of the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice. The program receives funds from the Office of Alternative Dispute Resolution, which in turn receives appropriations through the FEW appropriations account of the Department of Justice. The Office of Alternative Dispute Resolution funds mediation for litigating units within the Department of Justice, including the ADA Mediation Program. Funding requests for the program are limited, hindering personnel increase and training. Specific expertise is required for voluntary mediation under the Americans with Disabilities Act to serve the disability community effectively. The ADA Mediation Program, funded by the Office of Alternative Dispute Resolution, facilitates voluntary mediation to resolve disputes under the Americans with Disabilities Act. The program may hire personnel and provide training to better serve the disability community. The ADA Mediation Program, funded by the Office of Alternative Dispute Resolution, may hire additional personnel and provide training for mediators. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2019 to carry out this section. The ADA Mediation Program can use funds to pay for obligations incurred before the enactment of this section. SEC. 4. ADA INFORMATION LINE DATA COLLECTION REPORT. Congress finds that the ADA Information Line has answered approximately 38,135 calls during fiscal year 2018, receiving about 1,000 calls per week from various individuals and entities interested in the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. ADA.gov provides resources for individuals and entities seeking information on the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The ADA Information Line offers assistance and materials related to the Act's requirements and regulations. The term "disability" is defined in accordance with the Act. The Attorney General will submit a report to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment, outlining calls received by the ADA Information Line, efforts to educate about the line, and recommendations for improving support for individuals and entities covered by the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990.
